item.title: Spatial decoding of endosomal cAMP signals by a metastable cytoplasmic PKA network
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00747-0

High mobility and nuclear translocation of the PKA catalytic subunit, PKAcat, relays signals induced by endosomal cAMP generated through endocytosis and signaling from the G-protein-coupled receptor β2-adrenergic receptor.
item.dc:title: Spatial decoding of endosomal cAMP signals by a metastable cytoplasmic PKA network
item.dc:creator: Grace E. Peng
Veronica Pessino
Bo Huang
Mark von Zastrow
item.dc:source: Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 2021-03-01; | doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00747-0

item.title: Oncohistone mutations enhance chromatin remodeling and alter cell fates
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00738-1

Combined use of a DNA-barcoded nucleosome library and a humanized yeast library allows the identification of histone globular domain mutations that affect histone exchange and nucleosome sliding processes, as well as cancer-associated gene pathways.
item.dc:title: Oncohistone mutations enhance chromatin remodeling and alter cell fates
item.dc:creator: John D. Bagert
Michelle M. Mitchener
Agata L. Patriotis
Barbara E. Dul
Felix Wojcik
Benjamin A. Nacev
Lijuan Feng
C. David Allis
Tom W. Muir
item.dc:source: Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 2021-03-01; | doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00738-1

item.title: Redox control of flowering
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 25 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00758-x

Using an interdisciplinary approach, hydrogen-peroxide-induced phase separation in the intrinsically disordered regions of the TERMINATING FLOWER transcription factor proteins was shown to regulate the shoot apical meristem through repression of the floral identity gene called ANANTHA.
item.dc:title: Redox control of flowering
item.dc:creator: Christine H. Foyer
item.dc:source: Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 2021-02-25; | doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00758-x

item.title: ROS regulated reversible protein phase separation synchronizes plant flowering
item.content:encoded:
Nature Chemical Biology, Published online: 25 February 2021; doi:10.1038/s41589-021-00739-0

Plants utilize naturally produced ROS in shoot apical stem cells as a developmental signal to trigger phase separation of TMF. The resulting transcriptional condensates repress expression of the floral identity gene to precisely time flowering.
item.dc:title: ROS regulated reversible protein phase separation synchronizes plant flowering
item.dc:creator: Xiaozhen Huang
Shudong Chen
